show.desc: Whether to show the timeline component. It would not show with a setting of false, but its functions still remain.

type.desc: This attribute has only one valid value as slider by now. You don't have to change it.

axisType.desc:
Type of axis, whose values may be: 

* 'value' Numeric axis, which is suitable for continuous data.
* 'category' Category axis, which is suitable for category data.
* 'time' Time axis, which is suitable for continuous time data. Compared with value axis, time axis is equipped with time formatting function and has a different method when calculating axis ticks. For example, for time axis, axis ticks may vary in choosing unit as month, week, date, or hour based on the range of data.

currentIndex.desc: Indicates which is the currently selected item. For instance, if currentIndex is 0, it indicates that the currently selected item is timeline.data[0] (namely, using options[0]).

playInterval.desc: Indicates play speed (gap time between two state), whose unit is millisecond.

realtime.desc: Whether the view updates in real time during dragging the control dot.

replaceMerge.desc:
When initializing, a switchableOption corresponding to the current time tick are merged into baseOption to form the finalOption. Each time the current tick changed, the new switchableOption corresponding to the new time tick are merged into the finalOption. There are two merging strategy. 

* By default, use NORMAL_MERGE.
* If [timeline.replaceMerge][0] is set, use REPLACE_MERGE. See [setOption][1] for more details of REPLACE_MERGE.

  
The value of replaceMerge can be a mainType of a component, like replaceMerge: 'xAxis', or an array of mainTypes, like replaceMerge: ['xAxis', 'series']. replaceMerge is usually used in this scenario: if users intending to replace all of the current series with the new series corresponding to the next time tick without any merging, users can set: replaceMerge: 'series', and make sure that the series are in different id or no id. See this [example][2].

[0]: #option.html#timeline.replaceMerge
[1]: #api.html#echartsInstance.setOption
[2]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/timeline-dynamic-series&edit=1&reset=1

controlPosition.desc: Position of the play button, whose valid values are 'left' and 'right'.

zlevel.desc: zlevel value of all graphical elements in . zlevel is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different zlevel values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate zlevel. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid crash. Canvases with bigger zlevel will be placed on Canvases with smaller zlevel.

z.desc: z value of all graphical elements in , which controls order of drawing graphical components. Components with smaller z values may be overwritten by those with larger z values. z has a lower priority to zlevel, and will not create new Canvas.

left.desc: Distance between timeline component and the left side of the container. left value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'left', 'center', or 'right'. If the left value is set to be 'left', 'center', or 'right', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

top.desc: Distance between timeline component and the top side of the container. top value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'; and it can also be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom'. If the left value is set to be 'top', 'middle', or 'bottom', then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

right.desc: Distance between timeline component and the right side of the container. right value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'. Adaptive by default.

bottom.desc: Distance between timeline component and the bottom side of the container. bottom value can be instant pixel value like 20; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like '20%'. Adaptive by default.

orient.desc:
Orientation of the component, whose valid values are: 

* 'vertical': vertical layout.
* 'horizontal': horizontal layout.

inverse.desc: * Whether to put the timeline component reversely, which makes the elements in the front to be at the end.

symbol.desc:
Symbol of timeline. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

symbolSize.desc: timeline symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of timeline symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

symbolOffset.desc: Offset of timeline symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

lineStyle.show.desc: Whether to show the axis. It can be set to be false to hide the axis line to make a different style.

lineStyle.color.desc:
timeline Line color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

lineStyle.type.desc:
line type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With dashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    type: [5, 10],
    
    dashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With type , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

label.desc: Label axis, emphasis is the highlighted style of text. For instance, text style in emphasis would be used when mouse hovers or legend connects.

label.position.desc:
Configurations: 

* 'auto': Automatic layout.
* 'left': Put it along the left margin. It is valid when [timline.orient][0] is set as 'horizontal' .
* 'right': Put it along the right margin. It is valid when [timline.orient][0] is set as 'horizontal'.
* 'top': Put it along the margin of the top. It is valid when [timline.orient][0] is set as 'vertical'.
* 'bottom': Put it along the margin of the bottom. It is valid when [timline.orient][0] is set as 'vertical'.
* number: When it is assigned to be a a number value, it indicates the distance between label and axis. If it is set to be 0 , label would be at the same position with axis. Negative value is valid for the other side of the axis.



[0]: #timeline.orient

label.interval.desc: Interval of label. When it is assigned with a numerical value, such as 2, a label would show every 2 items.

label.rotate.desc: Rotation angle of label, in which positive values refer to counter clockwise rotation.

label.fontWeight.desc:
timeline.lable font thick weight. Options are: 

* 'normal'
* 'bold'
* 'bolder'
* 'lighter'
* 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

label.fontFamily.desc: timeline.lable font family. Can also be 'serif' , 'monospace', ...

label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example：

    }

>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

progress.label.rich.<style_name>.borderR.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

progress.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

progress.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowC.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

progress.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowB.desc: Show blur of the text block.

progress.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

progress.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

progress.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

progress.label.rich.<style_name>.textBor.desc: Storke line width of the text.

Stroke line type of the text. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    textBorderType: [5, 10],
    
    textBorderDashOffset: 5
    }

emphasis.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

emphasis.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

emphasis.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: timeline border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: timeline border width. No border when it is set to be 0. timeline border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

emphasis.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

emphasis.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

emphasis.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

emphasis.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.
